description: From Latin relapsus, past participle of relabi (“to slide back, fall back”), from re- (“back”) + labi (“to slip, slide, fall”).

entries.meaning: The act or situation of relapsing.
(medicine) An occasion when a person becomes ill again after a period of improvement
(obsolete) One who has relapsed, or fallen back into error; a backslider.

verbs.description: relapse (third-person singular simple present relapses, present participle relapsing, simple past and past participle relapsed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To fall back again; to slide or turn back into a former state or practice.
examples: He has improved recently but keeps relapsing into states of utter confusion.
to relapse into a stupor, into vice, or into barbarism
to relapse into slumber after being disturbed

entries.meaning: (intransitive, medicine, of a disease) To recur; to worsen, be aggravated (after a period of improvement).
(intransitive, informal, specifically) To return to a vice, especially self-harm or alcoholism, failing to maintain abstinence.
examples: relapsed after 5 months of being clean

entries.meaning: To slip or slide back physically; to turn back.
